column4: there is a difference between "PSHUFD" and "PSHUFD site:http://www.ews.uiuc.edu/~cjiang/reference/"
Yes there is. Go into the search line of google.com for example, '?right click' set keyword.'
I use the keyword goo for google for example. For a google search I do <ctrl>l goo wifi jaunty for example
thats nice, but i can't think of a way this could insert site: into the query without me entering it by hand
like i'm browsing ubuntu.com, type "something" in search box and it would go to google with the query: "something site:ubuntu.com"
So you would like to search ubuntu.com for the keyword 'something'?
that was just an example, but yes
You can add a keyword for all searches you want. So if ubuntu.com had a 'search engine' (it has), you could give that the 'ubu' keyword and do a 'ubu something' search.
That's the best option I can give you.
i want to use it for sites that do not have search engines, thats the point
I see what you mean. So what's the problem of typing <ctrl>l iraq site:cnn.com
it's at least 13 letters to type more for that short an url

Again I see what you mean. All I can say is, that the firefox keyword feature is one of the most important for me and I see not a hugh difference in searching for 'iraq sites: cnn.com' and 'cnn iraq', using the keyword feature in combination with the cnn search engine. If thete is no search engine, indeed you would have to 'iraq sites:somepage.net
